Introduction
This is an overview, and Table of Contents, for the worksheets distributed here. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

paragraphs.title: Section RREF: Reduced Row-Echelon Form
paragraphs.p: Construct two matrices, learning Sage syntax. Row-reduce each.

paragraphs.title: Section NM: Reduced Row-Echelon Form
paragraphs.p: Demonstrate Definition NM, Theorem NMRRI, Definition NSM, Theorem NMUS. Experiment with random vectors of constants. Foreshadow the column space of a matrix. Preliminary work with vector spaces (membership).

paragraphs.title: Section SS: Spanning Sets
paragraphs.p: For Section LC, I illustrate Theorem VFSLS by writing the row-reduced version of an augmented matrix with white chalk for the pivot columns (first columns of an identity matrix), white chalk for the zero rows, and then different colors for each of the remaining columns. Then the vectors that describe the solution get the same numbers, or their negatives, in the same colors. But first I place the pattern of zeros and ones in place in white. Part of the entries in white is that they are known from just knowledge of the sets D and F. This example gets recycled in this Sage worksheet on the following day. This is similar to Example VFSAI.
Null spaces, spans and membership round out the topics. There is some foreshadowing of bases for subspaces.

paragraphs.title: Section MISLE: Matrix Inverses and Systems of Linear Equations
paragraphs.p: A computational illustration of Theorem CINM and its proof. A nonsingular matrix versus a singular matrix.

paragraphs.title: Section CRS: Column and Row Space
paragraphs.p: A detailed demonstration of Theorem CSCS, in both directions. You could do this quickly, or you could linger a while and drive the point home.

paragraphs.title: Section FS: Four Subspaces
paragraphs.p: Computations of all the constituent matrices of extended echelon form, and exercises exploring the matrices J and L for an 8\times 10 matrix.

paragraphs.title: Section B: Bases
paragraphs.p: Theme: express vectors from \mathbb{C}^n as (unique) linear combinations of basis vectors. Techniques include solving systems, inverting matrices, obtaining a coordinatization from Sage, and Theorem COB for an orthonormal basis. The second and fourth exercises each has several parts.
